Peripheral and Enteral Nutrition

IBW M k g = 50 k g + 2.3 ( Height i n - 60 i n ) IBW F k g = 45.5 k g + 2.3 ( Height i n - 60 i n ) N B W = I B W + 0.25 * ( w t - I B W )

TMR=BMR*Factor

Max Carbohydrate Utilization: 4-5 mg/kg/min

Max Daily Fat Content: 2.5 g/kg/d, NTE 60% of Daily Calories

Glucose3.4

Propofol1.1 kcal/mL

Nitrogen balance is a measurment of the net change in nitrogen in an individuals body. In a healthy individual, the nitrogen balance should be approximatly 0. In a catabolic individual (patients suffering from sepsis, burns, majory surgery, etc) will exhibit a negative nitrogen balance, which is not ideal as this means they are breaking down protein at a higher rate than they are producing it. This lost nitrogen must be repleated to allow the individual to enter an anabolic state and repair cellular damage. A goal nitrogen balance for a hospitalized patient is (+)3-(+)5.

Nitrogen In ( g ) = 24hr Protein Intake ( g ) 6.25 Nitrogen Out ( g ) = 24hr UUN ( g ) + 4 ( g )

Malnutrition Risk Factors

    >10% wt loss within 6 months OR >5% within 1 month) Wt 20% under IBW) NPO >7-10 days Increased metabolic needs (trauma, burn, major surgery, etc) Inadequate nutrient intake

Enteral Nutrition

Short term EN is indicated in patients who will need EN for less than 3 weeks, and who have trouble swallowing, head or neck surgery, trauma or burns, esophageal obstruction, dysphagia, or any condition preventing normal eating. Options for short term EN administration include ND, NJ, and NG tubes (and their oral variations).

Long term EN is indicated for the same reasons as short term for periods of time longer than 3 weeks. Options for long term EN include jejunostomy and gastrostomy.

Drug Administration via EN Tube

    Check Medication Compatibility with EN Administration Crush Medication Administer via EN tube w/ 5mL sterile water rinse Repeat 2-3 for each medication Final 30mL sterile water rinse

Avoid mixing liquid medications with EN solution, as it may cause incompatibilites

Uncloging Feeding Tubes

    Pancreatic Enzyme Tablet Sodium Bicarb Tablet 10mL Warm Water

Contraindications

    Needed less than 5-10d Severe acute pancreatitis Proximal fistulas Severe vomitting and diarrhea GI Ischemia Ileus

Monitoring Parameters

Stool Count and Consistency X
Abdominal Distention X

Parenteral Nutrition

Access

PN can be administered via peripheral veins (PPN) or central veins (CPN or Central PN). Remember, PICC (Peripherally Inserted Central Catheters) are inserted peripherally, but lead to a central vein and are considered CPN. PICC lines are used for 2-6 week therapy or home use. Longer therapies should consider a central line.

Limitations and Concerns with PPN

Dextrose NTE 12.5%, Ca and Phos content must be monitored, and Osm NTE 900-1100 mOsm/L. PPN is not recommended for longer than 5 days due to the need to change sites to prevent infection, and for patients in need of considerable volumes of calories or electrolyte solutions.

PN Indications

Lack of GI Function AND NPO > 7d Ex.

    Bowel Ischemia Intractable V/D GI Obstruction Severe Inflammatory Bowel Disease Short Bowel Syndrome

PN Contrindications

  • Functioning GI Tract
  • Needed for < 7 days AND w/o malnutrition
  • Inability to gain access
  • Fat Emulsions are contraindicated w/ egg allergies due to egg yolk phospholipid contents

Essential Fatty Acid Deficiency (EFAD)

Symptoms: Dry Skin, immune complications, thrombocytopenia, alopecia, and mental development delays (peds only) 4-10% of daily calories should be linoleic and linolenic acid to prevent EFAD

Micronutrient Requirements

Do NOT Correct Major Electrolyte Imbalances w/ TPN

Micronutrient Quantity Comments
Na 1-2 mEq/kg/d Added as chloride, acetate, or phos depending on fluid balance of patient
K 1-2 mEq/kg/d Added as chloride, acetate or phos
Phos 20-40 mmol/d 1 mmol phos provides 1.33 mEq NA or 1.47 mEq K
Ca 10-15 mEq/d Added as gluconate; watch for precipitation w/ phos
Mg 8-20 mEq/d High demand in catabolic patients
Vitamins RDA
Trace Elements RDA Zn, Cu, Mn, Cr, and Se

Chloride vs Acetate Salts: Higher chloride ratio in metabolic alkalosis patients due to K deficiency, vomiting, or gastric decompression. Increased acetate ratio in renal failure or metabolic acidosis because acetate is converted to bicarb 1:1. Typical ratio is 2/3 chloride and 1/3 acetate.

Other PN Additives

  • H2-Antagonists
  • Insulin: Hyperglycemic patients should receive 0.1 units/g dextrose (per 3.4 kcal dextrose), and is generally not useful unless >10 units are administered (insulin binds to the TPN bag). Patients with a large insulin requirement should be on a separate insulin drip
  • Heparin (generally not used)
  • Albumin SHOULD NEVER be added to PN due to increased microbial growth

PN Complications

  • Mechanical
    • Infusion Pump Failure
    • Pneumothorax
    • Catheter migration
    • Improper catheter positioning
    • Arterial Puncture
  • Infections
  • Metabolic
    • Liver Disease
    • Hypertriglyceridemia
    • Hyperglycemia
    • Refeeding Syndrome
    • EFAD
    • Metabolic Bone Disease

Refeeding Syndrome

Refeeding Syndrome is marked by severe fluid an electrolyte abnormalities arising with the sudden influx of nutrients to malnourished individuals

Symptoms

  • Seizures
  • Coma
  • Arrhythmias
  • Lactic Acidosis
  • Fluid Overload
  • Pulmonary Edema
  • Death

Prevention of Refeeding Syndrome

WATCH Mg, K, and Phos

  1. Identify At-Risk Patients (Elderly and Malnourished)
  2. Correct Electrolyte Abnormalities BEFORE Starting TPN
  3. AVOID OVERFEEDING
  4. Start Normal Pts at 50% of daily caloric intake and At-Risk Patients at 25% of daily caloric intake. Increase to goal over 3-5d

TPN Administration

Writing a TPN

  1. Obtain pertinent info from pt’s chart
  2. Calculate goal caloric needs
  3. Calculate goal protein
  4. Find non-protein calories
  5. Find appropriate volumes of all nutrients
  6. Add volume for micronutrients (typically 150mL)
  7. Divide by 24 hours for flow rate
  8. Remember to start at 50% or less of daily caloric needs
  9. Order monitoring parameters

Initiation of TPN

  1. Write an appropriate TPN
  2. Administer w/ proper filter (0.22mcm for 2-in-1, or 1.2 mcm for 3-in-1)
  3. Increase to meet goals and monitor

D/C TPN

Taper the TPN as the patient transitions, and remember to d/c insulin

Cycling TPNs

Do not administer > 200mL/hr

Special Populations

Cardiac Disease

Avoid overfeeding and restrict fluids

Diabetes

Keep BG between 140-180 mg/dL in critically ill patients, or 110-220 mg/dL normally. Give 30% of total daily kcals as fat, and give an agent to stimulate gastric emptying (like erythromycin) if using EN in type 1 diabetics.

GERD

Add H2 antagonist or PPI. Add to TPN if possible.

Hepatic Disease

35 kcal/kg/d, 1-1.2 g/kg/d protein w/o encephalopathy (0.6 w/ encephalopathy, think about ammonia production). Restrict sodium w/ edema

N/V or NG Suction

May lead to acid-base or electrolyte imbalance, monitor.

Pulmonary Disease

20-30 kcal/kg, and 30%-50% of TOTAL kcal as fat. 1-2 g/kg protein. Limit carbohydrates (see indirect calorimetry and relative CO2 production) and AVOID OVERFEEDING

Renal Disease

Fluid restrictions

Pre-dialysis

Use 0.5-0.8 g/kg if patient is otherwise normal w/ CrCl < 30 mL/min or 0.5-1 g/kg if patient has CrCl < 30 mL/min and is post-op

Dialysis

Standard Protein amounts. In pts w/ intermittent HD (HD MWF), 1-1.3 g/kg. Pts on CRRT give 1.5-2 g/kg

Short Bowel Syndrome

With colon, use a high carb-low fat diet. Vit B12 supplementation should be considered

Wound Healing

Add Zn and Vit C

References

ASPEN Guidlines for Adult Critically Ill Patients

Author: Corbin Cox
